> public void testIncrementBy() {

> counter.incrementBy(5);
> assertEquals("incremented value", 5, counter.getCount());

<snip />

You could also try reading the question. :) :) :) That looks suspiciously like using a get method.

To the OP, there are a number of ways to answer that question, depending on the actual design under test. If you can give us some information on what the 'void' method does, we may have a suggestion for you.

Consider the event/listener design in Java. An event source exposes 'addXXXListener' and 'removeXXXListener', but no methods to query the list of listeners. After all, only the event source needs to know who the listeners are at any given moment.

You want to test 'addXXXListener' to see whether it really does add the listener. You have two choices.

1. Add 'containsXXXListener' to the event source and use it in your tests. This is essentially the 'get' method you don't want to use.

2. Add a listener to the event source, tell the event source to fire an event, then check that the listener heard the event.

Option #1 is cleaner, although it adds a method 'just for testing'. Rather than drag up my past comments in that direction, I suggest searching this group for the phrase "just for testing" and read the messages you find.

Option #2 avoids the extra method, but relies on knowing how to fire an event, which kind of event is fired and building a listener that listens for that kind of event *and* can tell you whether it heard that event. That was a lot to type: the code must be more work! Also if the event source changes its internal workings, your test may no longer work. With Option #1, there's not much danger in the event source changing in a way that might break your test.

For details, look for "JUnit Cookbook" from Manning publications, although you'll have to be patient -- it may not be on the shelf until early 2004.

Take care.
